value.Title: At Least Nine People Are Dead, 16 Injured And 17 More Are In Critical Condition After A Man Plowed His Van Into Pedestrians In One Of The Busiest Thoroughfares In Toronto, Canada. The Man Is Now In Custody But Toronto Police Has Not Release Yet His Identity; Secretary Of State Nominee Mike Pompeo Is Now Being Voted On The Floor Of The Senate Relations Committee But Democrats Has Oppose His Nomination; Republican Senator Rand Paul First Oppose Pompeo's Nomination But Eventually Said In A Tweet That He Will Support The CIA Director; President Trump With First Lady Melania Welcomes To The White House French President Emmanuel Macron And Wife Brigitte For His First State Visit As President; French President Emmanuel Macron And His Wife Brigitte Gave A Sapling Of Oak Tree As A Gift To President Trump To Plant In The White House. That Sapling Came From Belleau Wood In France Where Over 9,000 American Marines Have Died During World War I; The Voting For CIA Director As Secretary Of State To Replace Rex Tillerson Is Now Underway On The Floor Of The Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Senators Jeff Flake And Rand Paul Also Voted Yes; Hallmarks Of Terrorism Is Seen In The Toronto Truck Attack That Took Nine Lives And Injured 16 Others But Toronto Police Hasn't Ruled That Conclusion Yet As Investigation Is Still Ongoing; Google Is Now In The Hot Seat Over Their Data Privacy Practices After A New Report Shows That Google Is Collecting And Keeping People's Personal Information Way Worse Than Facebook

Extracts.SummaryText: ... A lot of people are saying Google is one of a kind so if you are an investor you like to hear that. The flip side is, will it make regulators consider one of a kind akin to monopoly which is not too far of a stretch. We do know that the European regulators are putting in new privacy laws as of May 25th of this year so tech companies, ones that are based here but have customers in Europe, need to be compliant. If these companies are not compliant this is not a small slap on the wrist, Liz, ...

urn:contentItem:5S5X-J7H1-JBHT-D44P-00000-00At Least Nine People Are Dead, 16 Injured And 17 More Are In Critical Condition After A Man Plowed His Van Into Pedestrians In One Of The Busiest Thoroughfares In Toronto, Canada. The Man Is Now In Custody But Toronto Police Has Not Release Yet His Identity; Secretary Of State Nominee Mike Pompeo Is Now Being Voted On The Floor Of The Senate Relations Committee But Democrats Has Oppose His Nomination; Republican Senator Rand Paul First Oppose Pompeo's Nomination But Eventually Said In A Tweet That He Will Support The CIA Director; President Trump With First Lady Melania Welcomes To The White House French President Emmanuel Macron And Wife Brigitte For His First State Visit As President; French President Emmanuel Macron And His Wife Brigitte Gave A Sapling Of Oak Tree As A Gift To President Trump To Plant In The White House. That Sapling Came From Belleau Wood In France Where Over 9,000 American Marines Have Died During World War I; The Voting For CIA Director As Secretary Of State To Replace Rex Tillerson Is Now Underway On The Floor Of The Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Senators Jeff Flake And Rand Paul Also Voted Yes; Hallmarks Of Terrorism Is Seen In The Toronto Truck Attack That Took Nine Lives And Injured 16 Others But Toronto Police Hasn't Ruled That Conclusion Yet As Investigation Is Still Ongoing; Google Is Now In The Hot Seat Over Their Data Privacy Practices After A New Report Shows That Google Is Collecting And Keeping People's Personal Information Way Worse Than Facebook2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:18ZLexisNexisAt Least Nine People Are Dead, 16 Injured And 17 More Are In Critical Condition After A Man Plowed His Van Into Pedestrians In One Of The Busiest Thoroughfares In Toronto, Canada. The Man Is Now In Custody But Toronto Police Has Not Release Yet His Identity; Secretary Of State Nominee Mike Pompeo Is Now Being Voted On The Floor Of The Senate Relations Committee But Democrats Has Oppose His Nomination; Republican Senator Rand Paul First Oppose Pompeo's Nomination But Eventually Said In A Tweet That He Will Support The CIA Director; President Trump With First Lady Melania Welcomes To The White House French President Emmanuel Macron And Wife Brigitte For His First State Visit As President; French President Emmanuel Macron And His Wife Brigitte Gave A Sapling Of Oak Tree As A Gift To President Trump To Plant In The White House. That Sapling Came From Belleau Wood In France Where Over 9,000 American Marines Have Died During World War I; The Voting For CIA Director As Secretary Of State To Replace Rex Tillerson Is Now Underway On The Floor Of The Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Senators Jeff Flake And Rand Paul Also Voted Yes; Hallmarks Of Terrorism Is Seen In The Toronto Truck Attack That Took Nine Lives And Injured 16 Others But Toronto Police Hasn't Ruled That Conclusion Yet As Investigation Is Still Ongoing; Google Is Now In The Hot Seat Over Their Data Privacy Practices After A New Report Shows That Google Is Collecting And Keeping People's Personal Information Way Worse Than FacebookLanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Being confirmed for you tonight, right now, there are nine people that are dead, 16 that are injured. Toronto police service has mobilized all available resources and I can assure the public all available resources have been brought into address this tragic situation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, HOST, FOX NEWS: Breaking news to the developing situation in Toronto, a driver now in custody after plowing a van into a crowd among Toronto's busiest thoroughfares, nine dead, 16 injured 17 critically.

I am Elizabeth MacDonald. This is Risk & Reward.

The mayor of Toronto authorities just now holding a press conference, the mayor saying it will likely be several days of disruption to the area during the investigation.

Here with more let's get to Kristina Partsinevelos in the newsroom. Kristina?

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: Yes, this event only happened a few hours ago at 1.30 p.m. Eastern Time. A white van from the company Ryder, it's a rental van company plowed on to the sidewalk, what you're seeing right now, started to hit a few pedestrians. According to eye witnesses the pedestrians asked the van to stop, the driver continued going hitting more pedestrians.

And as you mentioned there are nine dead, 16 injured. There's still no word yet about the motivation behind this van attack. You had the mayor just speak very recently, the Mayor of Toronto that's John Tory, and he said we are admired the around the world for being inclusive doesn't want anybody to jump to conclusions just yet as to the motive behind this attack.

Very importantly to note as well, this is the remaining a Toronto investigation not a national investigation with the RCMP, the Royal Canadian Mountain Police, again, this is a Toronto investigation they are not releasing the name of the driver of the van but they were able to bring him into custody.

He seemed uninjured based off of several eye witness videos that I've seen when they caught him, he happened to have something in his hand. There's still no confirmation what he was carrying but he was pointing it at a police officer. There were no shots fired.

Again, this man is in custody. We do not have any details just yet on who he is, what his motivation is, are the Toronto police are being very careful right now with the information, making sure going through to see if he had any cell phones looking through his records to see most importantly if he is somebody that they recognize, that they know and could be affiliated with other people, but right now this is a Toronto investigation.

You have several, 16 people still injured and businesses that have been damaged along the road because this white van went up on to the sidewalk, hit pedestrians, even rammed into a bus station. There was one eye witness that said he saw his family they're looking for their grandfather and they're very worried and I was just listening to this live through Canadian media that they found the grandfather's glasses on the ground and so they're still waiting confirmation.

Several of the patients or victims have been brought to Sunny Brook Hospital in Toronto, again Sunny Brook Hospital, so again we have nine dead, 16 injured in this tragic event that's happening in Toronto as we speak.

MACDONALD: Thank you, Kristina. We'll be staying on top of that story and much more.

Let's get to your money. A widely held stock making lots of 401k plans going up. Google parent company Alphabet reporting solid earnings and revenues better than expected after the bell.

Let's get to Deirdre Bolton on the latest with that. Deirdre?

DEIRDRE BOLTON, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: Hey, Liz. So after-hours, you are going to see this stock kind of see sawing back and forth. So it had a big reaction as you mentioned, Alphabet, Google exceeding both on the top and bottom line and you had a jump of around 4 percent initially, so you can see still higher.

But just coming off those posted session highs, there are still some really big questions out there, Liz, for the long term of this company. You know, Google has between eight to 10 times more data on you and on me than Facebook so a lot of Facebook investors were saying hey, how come Mark Zuckerberg got dragged before Congress?

Google has about eight gigabytes of data per person, that equals about 2,000 hours if we just listen straight through of music. If you want a comparison point Facebook has about 650 megabytes which are smaller than gigabytes and that equals about 160 hours of music. So just an interesting kind of data point and it just shows you where this data power is.

A lot of people are saying Google is one of a kind so if you are an investor you like to hear that. The flip side is, will it make regulators consider one of a kind akin to monopoly which is not too far of a stretch.

We do know that the European regulators are putting in new privacy laws as of May 25th of this year so tech companies, ones that are based here but have customers in Europe, need to be compliant. If these companies are not compliant this is not a small slap on the wrist, Liz, it is between $30 million or 4 percent of annual revenue whichever is higher, so there's a lot of people saying OK, Google has a lot of work ahead. Alphabet Google, excuse me. Liz?

MACDONALD: Good to see you, Deirdre. Thank you so much.

We have a jam packed busy hour ahead. We are moments away from President Trump and the first lady welcoming French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife at the White House for the administration's first official state dinner.

Let's get to Blake Burman with the latest. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: At the hour the French president has a busy couple of days here in Washington, Liz. I think you can see behind me that they are expecting Emmanuel Macron here at the White House within the next few minutes or so.

The itinerary is as follows. The Macron family, him and his wife, rather, and the president and first lady will head to dinner tonight to George Washington's home followed by talks tomorrow, a state dinner and then he addresses Congress on Wednesday.

The White House says these two have a great rapport, and part of the reason why he's receiving the first state visit. However, it is also clear that there are stark differences on a policy level, for example, there are trade issues at hand, as well as different views on the Iran nuclear deal and the Paris climate accord all will be discussed in the up upcoming days.

As we await Macron here at the White House, the White House as well also has its eyes on the goings up on Capitol Hill as it relates to the Senate foreign relations committee as the secretary of state nominee Mike Pompeo is set to get the thumbs down from the Senate foreign relations committee it appears within the next few minutes or so.

All 10 Democrats plus the Republican Rand Paul expected to vote against Pompeo to become the next secretary of state; however, Pompeo still expected to get a vote on the Senate floor and there it appears as though as if he will have the numbers to become the next secretary of state.

Today, two more Democrats came to his side saying that they would support him, Joe Manchin and Joe Donnelly, add to that Heidi Heitkamp to that group as well.

The White House is trying to make the argument to the United States Senate that if you voted for John Kerry and if you voted for Hillary Clinton, then you should vote for Mike Pompeo as well. The White House press secretary Sarah Sanders saying what's going on, on Capitol Hill sends this message to the rest of the world.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE-SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: What it says to the world is what we've been saying for a long time, the Senate has got some real problems, namely to figure out how to actually show up and do their job a little bit better.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now if Pompeo is voted down by the Senate foreign relations committee, Liz, that would be the first time that would ever happen to a secretary of state nominee if they eventually go on to become in that position.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Wow, historic times, Blake.

BURMAN: Yes.

MACDONALD: And by the way both Democrats and Republicans voted for Pompeo as CIA director.

BURMAN: Yes, CIA director.

MACDONALD: Good to see you, Blake.

BURMAN: You as well.

MACDONALD: Senate foreign relations committee, as Blake Burman just noted is about -- they are about to vote on Mike Pompeo to be secretary of state. Rand Paul tweeting out he will support the nomination he was against it.

Last month President Trump announced the departure of Rex Tillerson as secretary of state and as nomination of Pompeo as the replacement. Now the thinking is if it gets to the full chamber Pompeo will become the secretary of state. Just going through this process right now, we're monitoring the vote for you in the beginning.

Let's get to what's going on with the French visit. The media says this is going to be a bad relationship. Got off to a rocky start but now, French President Macron even taking a line from President Trump ahead of today's state visit to the White House. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, PRESIDENT OF FRANCE We have this very special relationship because both of us are probably the maverick of the system, on both sides I think President Trump's election was unexpected in your country, and probably my election wasn't expected in my country, and we are not part of the political system. I'm here to serve my people and my country and make it great again, somebody I know very well could say, but that's it, that's the whole story.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Joining me now, Weekly Standard executive editor, Fred Barnes. Fred, make France great again, did you hear that?

FRED BARNES, EXECUTIVE EDITOR, WEEKLY STANDARD: Yes, look, Macron, this is, he is so sure, so smart, so likable, and Trump is just basking in and he's getting everything he wants and Macron fought a big war and he wants to make sure that Trump doesn't get out of the Iran nuclear deal and that he gets back in the Paris accord, I think not much chance for that.

But he is smart. He is the big European leader who has stepped forward to embrace Trump, not endorse him but give Trump somebody big to deal with. It isn't going to be England, it isn't going to be what's the name, Angela Merkel in Germany comes in I think on Friday and that's just a bit of a sour puss and doesn't get along with Trump. But Macron has made an effort here and it's very wise on his part.

MACDONALD: You know, here is the thing. We've got that May 12 deadline for the Iran deal.

BARNES: Yes.

MACDONALD: The president is expected to yank it saying he already said this is the worst deal ever. So, and you're right, we've got Angela Merkel coming in. You know, Fred, these state visits are coming at a time when economic growth is up, optimism is up, the media reporting how the Democrats may take back control of the House.

The president seems to be dominating the message, when people go to vote they say, what are you going to do for me?

BARNES: Yes, look, I wouldn't buy this line from the Democrats and from a lot of people in the media that there's a blue wave coming and Democrats are just going to sweep through and win the House and maybe the Senate in November.

They do very well that would be what happens historically in the first mid- term election for a new president, but Trump is the dominant figure here and he has got some very optimistic things to talk about, not just the economy but in foreign policy as well.

Look, Macron was one of those who joined in the attack on the plants in Syria where they mix and made the poisonous product that were used to kill so many Syrians, so look, they worked together before and I think they'll work together again, particularly here.

MACDONALD: You know, Macron has pointed out that they're both maverick outsiders.

BARNES: They are.

MACDONALD: They're both businessmen, they're not part of the classical political system. Both were elected on the first try. It seems like these two men have a lot in common. So we've got the D.C. media up in arms saying, you know, this is again it's going to be problems here with the state visit, certainly with Angela Merkel, they're raising the red flags about it. What do you see?

BARNES: Well, look, I'll tell you what the media really wants and they're going to hound poor Macron while he's here. They want him to dump on Trump and he is refusing to do it, wouldn't be smart to do it.

MACDONALD: How are they going -- how are they going to get the French president to dump on President Trump?

BARNES: Well, he's going to have a press conference among other things, they'll yell questions at him, and look, they have ways to get that question asked, but Macron is I think not going to do it. What purpose of his would it serve? He says he's here to deal with the president of the United States. He doesn't have to and doesn't have to comment personally on Trump.

MACDONALD: You know what, to your point, Fred, and it's an important one. The media again, is misreading the situation.

BARNES: I think so.

MACDONALD: Macron likes his relationship with Trump because it improves his own basically rookie standing with the E.U. He's now being called the Trump whisperer. Macron is not going to damage that. He's not going to damage how important he is now to the E.U. given his relationship with Trump.

BARNES: I think you're absolutely right. It serves his purpose very well. Now, will Macron be able to talk Trump into not getting out of the Iran deal, will he be able to talk him to getting into Paris climate accord? I don't think so on either one of those things, but he'll get credit for trying.

MACDONALD: Good to see you, Fred Barnes. Great stuff. Come back soon.

BARNES: OK.

MACDONALD: Now let's get to this fast moving stock as Google parent Alphabet reporting strong earnings and revenue after the bell. It's been doing that every quarter since 2010. The stock is moving after-hours. another great quarter for Google. But now, this. A new report Google does get more personal information about you than even Facebook, as Deirdre Bolton just said 8 to 10 times of Facebook. We're going to show you the details.

We're also monitoring that Senate foreign relationships vote of Mike Pompeo as secretary of state. Rand Paul breaking news here, just putting out he will vote for Michael Pompeo, when the vote comes we're going to bring it to you. Liberal newspapers now supporting Pompeo. We're going to show who.

But first, we're also watching President Trump and the first lady welcoming French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife at the White House for the administration's first official state dinner. We're going to bring that to you live as well, jam-packed hour, really busy hour ahead, don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Back to this breaking news. We are monitoring French President Emmanuel Macron he's about to appear at the White House any second, but the first lady and the president will greet the French president and Mrs. Macron at the White House.

Let's bring in Trump 2020 campaign senior advisor Katrina Pierson. It's a historic visit, Katrina, now even President Macron effectively saying you know what? President is the president to the American people, he's giving that message the American people will deal with it. He's the president.

KATRINA PIERSON, TRUMP 2020 SENIOR ADVISOR: Absolutely. This truly is a refreshing display of leadership. You have two leaders who don't agree 100 percent on all of the policy positions but who have become friends and respect each other as leaders and now we're here having a great visit. I fully expect President Macron to make his case, with regards to trade and Syria and Iraq. But here, I mean, Iran.

So here is the thing. President Trump is going to consider the president of France as counsel absolutely as a courtesy, Liz. But let's make no mistake. The president of the United States will be making policy for the United States so I think this is a great opportunity for many in our own country to see how elected leaders should act.

MACDONALD: You know, to your point, it's well taken. Because the thinking in the E.U. as President Macron is the leading edge of that wedge to get the president to step back on the Iran deal, dial back on, you know, the tariffs, and the potential trade wars, and also climate change. But your point is President Trump is not going to do that, right?

PIERSON: No, I don't think so because these are things that the president has hold very dear and we've seen it throughout the campaign. You can go all the way back to the 80s on some of these positions. But I do think he would consider the counsel, but at the same time the president has made a commitment to the United States and that is to put America and its people first. That is not going to change. And I think the president of France respects the president's opinion as well.

And when we look at the things like Iran, for example, the president was very adamant on making some significant changes, things that a lot of people agree with, regardless of how we entered this deal. We have a new leader of the United States and he wants to have input.

MACDONALD: So again, we're monitoring this situation unfolding right now at the White House. You're looking at a live action shot of the White House, the president of France with the first lady of France expected to appear momentarily to greet the president and first lady Melania Trump.

President Macron to your point, Katrina, is expected to press President Trump on trade. Here is what he said over the weekend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MACRON: You cannot make it through the wall with the allies, it's too complicated. If you make war against everybody, you'll make trade war against China, trade war against Europe, war in Syria, war against them, come on, it doesn't work. You need ally. We are the ally.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: OK, so here is the messaging problem right for the president? Katrina, he's got to say listen we're not talking about trade war. We're talking about fair trade and the E.U. needs to get that message China has not been fair. Go ahead.

PIERSON: Well, absolutely, and we keep hearing that the president is doing this to everyone else when in fact, everyone else has done this to the United States and the president is simply saying look, we need fair and reciprocal trade.

At the end of the day that's what going to matter. Many people in our own country have doubted his ability to make these deals and to get things done, but if you look at ISIS and tax reform he's even been bringing North Korea to the table. So the president is actually doing things right. It might be different, but we're actually getting things done.

And I think President Macron is going to get to hear President Trump's position on these things as well.

MACDONALD: Here is an unfolding breaking news situation and it's happening right now with Russia and Iran as it pertains to the E.U. Katrina, to your point, record amounts of U.S. oil is now flooding into E.U. markets, that deal with Iran that Obama struck, there's a May 12 deadline that is looming the president could yank what he says is the worst deal ever and impose sanctions.

Again, Iran is backed by Russia, Russia supplies a lot of oil and Nat gas to the E.U. We are just hearing the breaking news that the U.S. is now becoming the number one oil exporter into the E.U changing geopolitical landscape in the favor of the U.S. right here, Katrina.

PIERSON: Well, and that's exactly what we call making America great again, and President Trump knows one thing and that is leverage. He wrote about it. And he knows and the world knows that if the president was to pull out of the Iran deal, perhaps go back to the sanctions on the Iran central bank or oil exports it's going to be a problem.

But these are things like, you know, looking at including the long range missiles and you know, eliminating the sunset provision on things like I don't know, you're reaching -- enriching uranium which is a huge problem for Iran.

MACDONALD: OK.

PIERSON: And the president of France they need to understand is we don't see the dust to France chance coming out of Iran like we see coming from Iran to America.

MACDONALD: To you--

(CROSSTALK)

PIERSON: And President Trump takes that very seriously.

MACDONALD: Well, they are now as you can see at the White House raising the welcoming flags 15 months into his presidency, the president is finally rolling out the red carpet for the president of France and what will happen after Macron appears they will go for a sunset dinner on the terrace of George Washington's home in Mount Vernon overlooking the Potomac.

Katrina, Macron is expected to, to your point, really prep the president on the Iran deal. He is the leader, he's seen by the E.U. as the Trump whisper that he can basically coax the president into staying in the Iran deal. Macron, though, watch this, Katrina, admitting though that that deal as the president has said has flaws. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MACRON: It this as if agreement perfect and this JCPOA a perfect thing for our relationship with Iran, no. But for nuclear, what do you have as a better option? I don't see it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: The car is now rolling up with the leader of France so Macron says that they would finish the war against ISIS. If we leave, we leave it open to Iran and Syria, they are going to fuel a new terrorist war. What are your thoughts?

PIERSON: Well, I think President Trump is also coming at this from a different perspective. You know, we've had this, that we've been doing the same thing over and over again expecting different results and President Trump doesn't want to do that anymore and he's not saying end it altogether, he wants to make revisions.

And now that we see that they're cracking down on anti-government protesters that's a problem particularly if we're just going to sit back and allow this to happen not really knowing what's going on.

MACDONALD: OK. Let me break in here. The president is just stepping outside the White House with the first lady ready to greet the president of France, and Mrs. Macron as well. Tomorrow night there will be a state dinner and a break with tradition, President Trump has invited no Democrat members of Congress or journalists. About 150 guests will take their seats in the state ding room tomorrow night.

It's going to be a more intimate affair than those held by President Barack Obama. Obama's guest list went into the hundreds and the president really wants to keep this close relationship. And here he is, the president of France greeting and a hug with the president of the United States. Let's watch this and let this moment sink in.

OK, Katrina, what we're watching now is a warm embrace between the leader of France and his wife is with the leader of the United States. It looks really quite collegial; they are now turning for the official photograph.

Katrina, Trump seems, the president seems to be going all out on pomp and circumstance. That's how much he had in Paris last July when the president of France invited him to watch the annual Bastille Day. What's your reaction to rolling out the red carpet for the president of France?

PIERSON: Well, it is Donald Trump, Liz, so I think we can fully expect the best with the president and Melania who, you know, is a class act in and of her own. I mean, it's just an amazing opportunity for us to all see what we're seeing right now and that is, you know, refreshing leadership, bringing two countries together, even though they have their differences, willing to work together for what they do agree upon.

MACDONALD: Our allies, Katrina, for 50 years. Katrina Pierson, thank you so much for weighing in there. I really appreciate it.

PIERSON: Great to be here. Thank you.

MACDONALD: OK. We're also monitoring this breaking developing situation, we're moments away from the Senate foreign relations vote on the nomination of CIA Director Mike Pompeo as secretary of state. Not the final confirmation the full chamber is expected to vote for Pompeo. A rebuke tough, Senate foreign relations don't want him. We're going to bring you that breaking news as it comes in. Don't go away, stay with us, more after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDERS: At some point, Democrats have to decide whether they love this country more than they hate this president, and they have to decide that they want to put the safety and the security and the diplomacy of our country ahead of their own political games, and we're very hopeful that they will.

Mike Pompeo is a highly qualified individual. He's been one of the leading people when it comes to the negotiations and the conversations with North Korea, and to stop that would be a incredibly dangerous and damaging for our country and for the world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: OK. We're staying in breaking news mode. We've got more developments, look at this. Republican Senator Jeff Flake now a yes on the nomination. He will vote yes that Pompeo should be secretary of state with Rand Paul. That means the Senate foreign relations panel is doing a 180.

Instead of rebuking this nomination it looks like the Senate foreign relations panel will confirm Mike Pompeo as secretary of state.

Let's bring in the Daily Caller editorial director, Vince Coglianese. What a turn around, Vince?

VINCE COGLIANESE, EXECUTIVE EDITOR, DAILY CALLER: That's quite a change of events. Rand Paul, of course the big hold out, you mentioned Jeff Flake as well, but Rand Paul, the president saying in public that he wanted to see Rand come with him, and that is happening, that's a huge deal.

And it's important that the Senate foreign relations committee do this, give him a stamp of approval given the unheard-of nature of sending out somebody with disapproval to be voted on by the full Senate approve.

MACDONALD: Yes, that's right. Let's get to the viewer, he comes out of Senate foreign relations, it looks like the Senate foreign relations panel does vote yes saying, yes, Pompeo should be the next secretary of state. Then it goes to the full Senate where Pompeo is expected to be confirmed as secretary of state.

You know, here's the thing, initially, Vince, the storyline was that, you know, they didn't like Pompeo's position on Iran.

COGLIANESE: Yes.

MACDONALD: They thought he was too much of a hawk. He was supposed to be the easy confirmation.

COGLIANESE: Yes

MACDONALD: He was supposed to be the no-brainer, and all of a sudden he was a problem that even Democrats and Republicans who voted for him as CIA director were saying, no, we don't want him as secretary of state in the middle of the North Korea breakthroughs.

COGLIANESE: Right.

MACDONALD: I mean, it is a stunning, you know, revelation of what's going on in D.C. when you have historic developments going on with North Korea. And they're saying no to Pompeo when he's trying to strike these deals. Go ahead.

COGLIANESE: Yes. And it was a temper tantrum that lead them to that conclusion, and I say that because this was a referendum on Trump. And all of the assessments that we've heard from Democrats it was about -- it was about Mike Pompeo's insufficient because he's not going to rein in Trump's worth instincts.

There's no evidence for that. As the head of the CIA, he's had an unblemished career there, he's had a good career prior to that as well. He was, as you said, confirmed by the Senate to run the CIA before including with Democratic support, and now he's got the opportunity to be secretary of state.

And there's such an important resume item there for Mike Pompeo, and you mentioned it. It's the fact that he's leading negotiations with North Korea. This is an historic moment in terms of just having a U.S. official leading such a high-level negotiation with North Korea.

To throw him out, to get rid of him as secretary of state would be a preposterous exercise in politics--

MACDONALD: Yes.

COGLIANESE: -- and one the Democrats should not suffer right now because if they do, they will suffer politically in the future politically for making such a horrendous decision.

MACDONALD: You know, historians and analysts have already said if the president gets that North Korea deal, it will be on the level of Reagan/Gorbachev.

We have three liberal newspapers saying, you know what? Obstructionist Democrats, stop. You have to put Pompeo in as secretary of state. The president needs be a secretary of state. They are, USA Today, a writer at the Washington Post, and the New York Daily News. Your final reaction, Vince.

COGLIANESE: Well, only that Barack Obama was given a Nobel Peace prize the moment he came into office for doing nothing. If this is accomplished, as you were mentioning, a peaceful North Korea of any kind, a meaningful peace and one that draws down nuclear weapons, then I expect that Donald Trump will receive a nomination for it, not that the Nobel Prize committee will ever seriously consider him.

He's not exactly beloved by the globalist communist, but Mike Pompeo should be right up there on that stage accepting the same thing. We have a long way to go before we get there, but this is a big deal, and Mike Pompeo should clear the bar at the United States Senate.

MACDONALD: OK. Great to see you, Vince.

Let's take you back to the White House. A truly lovely event is about to be, take place right now. The two couples will plant a tree. It's a gift from the president and president of France and Mrs. Macron they are going to plant a tree, a sapling, a European oak on the South Lawn of the White House about four and a half feet tall.

We're going to bring that to you live as it happens. Interesting note here, First lady Melania Trump is really taking the lead here in organizing this historic visit.

Quick, we're going to have more after the break. Also we're staying on the situation in Toronto, that van plowing down pedestrians. Nine dead, 17 injured, seven critically. We're going to bring you the latest on that. A suspect has been arrested. No motive yet. We will bring that to you live.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The nightmare, I've got to Yonge, and I've seen a lady with her leg -- man, it was a gruesome scene. It's really bad out there. I couldn't believe what I've seen, man. It was, man. Everybody, all these people on the streets getting hit one by one. Post office boxes getting crumpled up on people. And one person got dragged on and their blood is all over Yonge. It's really bad out there, man.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: OK. We are basically are watching the president with the first lady and the leader of France and the first lady of France now stepping out of the portico, the White House. They're now going to enter the South Lawn.

There's first lady Melania right there. She's been organizing this historic state visit. It is the White House's first state visit 15 months into the Trump presidency.

They're going to plant a tree on the South Lawn. It is a gift from France to the United States. It is a European oak sapling, four and a half feet tall.

We have lieutenant general Thomas McInerney here. Sir, this is a developing situation as well. General, the E.U. is look to the president of France to coax President Donald Trump to stay in the Iran nuclear deal. Your reaction.

THOMAS MCINERNEY, RETIRED UNITED STATES AIR FORCE: Well, it's natural, and they send President Macron over here to use him because he probably has the best relationship of any of the European leaders right now, so I'm not surprise. I do not think the president is going to change. He knows what he wants to do.

The Europeans on the Iranian deal, it's purely a cash cow. They're ignoring the nuclear threat per se. It's cash. They've got a huge trade surplus going, and they're working it to their advantage. But that's not good enough.

MACDONALD: You know, it seems when you read, study what the president of France, general, has been saying about ISIS leaving Syria and Iran's growing presence with military bases in Syria, on the one hand the president of France is saying as soon as -- if we leave, if we, the United States, leave Syria, Iran will step in and cause terrorist activities to go on the increase.

But at the same time, he wants the president to stay in the Iran nuclear deal. Can you square this for the viewer, can you explain that and sort that out?

MCINERNEY: Yes, I'll make it very simple. We should stay with the limited number of people in Syria with 24/7 air power, so if they try to take over any of the Kurdish places or the Syrian allies, then we can use that air power to beat them down and to defeat them.

Now, as far as the nuclear deal goes, that was such a bad deal that no agreement should ever have been made, the JCPOA, Liz. And we should back out of that from both a military and a political point of view. Again, remember, the European Union's interest is primarily in trade.

MACDONALD: Let me just give you some background information about the tree that was just planted. There is historic information about the reason that France gave the United States and the White House this tree.

Over 9,000 American marines died in World War I in what's called the Belleau Wood, this tree is from the area of that battle in June 1918 where 9,000 American marines died in World War I. That as far is a memorial site. It's an important symbol of the sacrifice the United States made to insure peace and stability in Europe.

General, your reaction to the president of France giving this oak tree to the United States in commemoration of World War I marines dying there.

MCINERNEY: Liz, it's very, very symbolic. The Battle of Belleau Wood was a horrendous battle. We lost, as you said, 9,000 marines. And to make this tree come from that region really touches on our relationship. And I think it is a very symbolic gesture by President Macron and symbolic of the relationship between the president and President Trump.

MACDONALD: What does this do for the psyche of the Trump administration, to have these memorable events come up and in the ensuing days? This will be a three-day visit, the president of Germany -- Germany, rather, Angela Merkel will be coming on Friday. How does this set the scene for the presidency of Donald Trump?

MCINERNEY: Well, I think it establishes it on a high note. People are seeing the way the Trumps handle their visitors and the relationships developing. The left has always wanted to deny that President Trump had that capability. He's absolutely brilliant at it. You're seeing it today and you'll see it at dinner tonight at Mount Vernon and the state dinner they have.

The whole three days that the Macrons are here and how they're honored is going to show the world and the American people what a great leader President Trump and Mrs. Trump are.

MACDONALD: We will be covering the Chancellor of Germany's visit, Angela Merkel as well, coming later this week. Good to see you, general. Thanks for coming in. I really appreciate it.

MCINERNEY: Thank, Liz.

MACDONALD: We are moments away from that Senate foreign relations vote on the nomination of CIA Director Mike Pompeo as secretary of state. Breaking news, it looks like that Senate panel will vote for Mike Pompeo to be secretary of state.

Jeff Flake and Rand Paul now saying they will vote for Michael Pompeo as secretary of state.

We're going to take you back to Toronto, van mowed down nine people, and injuring 16, killing nine in Toronto. We're going to bring you the latest on that after the break. Don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Being confirm for you tonight, right now, we have nine people that are dead. Sixteen that are injured. Toronto police service has mobilized all available resources, and I can assure the public all our available resources have been brought in to address this tragic situation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Take you to the developments in Toronto. Driver now in custody after plowing a van into a crowd leaving nine people dead, sixteen injured, seven critically. Toronto authorities held the press conference just moments ago. We still do not know the driver's identity and his motive, we will bring that to you as soon as it comes in.

General, listen, we have seen numerous van attacks like this and vehicular attacks, a dozen since 2006, general. We've seen them in England, we've seen them in Germany and Spain. And, of course, in Canada, as well as the U.S. Your reaction, sir.

MCINERNEY: Well, it looks like a cookie cutter, Liz. By the rental van, the number of people -- nine dead and 16 injured -- all the makings of radical Islam. All I need to know is the driver's name and a little more background, but I would say there's a 90 percent chance that this is radical Islam. It wasn't an old man that had a heart attack or a stroke.

MACDONALD: Again, we don't know the motive just yet. But we do know the facts about prior vehicular attacks. Let's talk about that. Again, we don't know the motive in Toronto.

General, you know, the terror capability has shifted. It is very difficult for terrorists -- we're not saying this is terrorism -- it's difficult for them to get bombs and explosives. It is easy for them to do vehicular attacks. Your reaction to that.

MCINERNEY: Well, that's exactly what ISIS is telling their warriors across the world, use vehicular attacks. And you can see all the ones that they've done in the last year rather than explosives or even weapons, although London are getting a lot of knives over there. But the fact is that is now their modus operandi, and it's something that we should be cognizant of, and it's very, very difficult to stop, Liz.

MACDONALD: You know, and to your point, the days of the terror cell are over. Now I think, to your point, terrorists -- and, again, we don't know the motives of this attack. It has the hallmark of a terrorist attack. Again, we'll bring you the motive as soon as it breaks.

To your point, general, you have said this before, ISIS and radical terrorist leaders are saying stay in place and do your own terrorism. This is a form of micro terrorism, right?

MCINERNEY: Exactly. And it's the patterns of behavior that I look at, that's my business, patterns of behavior. And this is what you're seeing now spread across all the cities in Europe as well as the United States in New York City, for instance, where you are. And so this is what we must expect, and it's extremely difficult to counter this.

MACDONALD: You know, it's a senseless act of violence. What do you say to the viewer out there, you know, these are just pedestrians walking on one of Toronto's busiest thoroughfares, it's just near downtown Toronto. Are we supposed to be having security barricades on every major block in every urban area, every city?

MCINERNEY: They would like that, but we're not going to do that.

MACDONALD: Why would they like that?

MCINERNEY: Because that means the western world is being influenced by the radical Islamists, to their way of thinking. They are putting control on what we do just like when we go to an airport and all the checks we go through. They like that.

But the fact is we've got to defeat this Islamic terrorism where the ideology comes from, Mecca and Medina from the Middle East, and that's the Muslims themselves. They must do that. And I'm hopeful that the new crown prince of Saudi Arabia will be the leader against the radical Islamists in his region so that they are no longer holy warriors and will go to paradise for killing infidels. No, we must destroy that ideology.

MACDONALD: It should be noted too that in Toronto a group of seven security international meeting was occurring just up -- a few blocks away from that terror attack. If we think -- let me back up, we don't know if it's a terror attack, it has the hallmarks of that. Sir, you know, what are the authorities asking this suspect right now?

MCINERNEY: Well, first of all, they want to get his name, and then you want to get where he goes to church, what his basic beliefs are, what is the reason he did this. If one person was killed, fine, that happens. But not nine people. Not nine people.

MACDONALD: General, good to see you, sir. Thank you so much for coming in and handling two stories. I really appreciate it.

MCINERNEY: Thanks, Liz.

MACDONALD: Again, we're going to take you back to the White House. This is -- we're in breaking news mode. The president and first lady welcoming French President Emmanuel Macron and the first lady of France, they're about to leave for Mount Vernon for a dinner overlooking at the Potomac. We will bring it to you live. That is the home of George Washington.

And we're also moments away from that vote out of the Senate panel on the nomination of CIA Director Mike Pompeo as secretary of state. It looks like that panel will vote for Mike Pompeo. Jeff Flake and Rand Paul saying yes to Mike Pompeo as secretary of state.

But first, after Facebook's data breach scandal, other big tech companies like Google could be next to face scrutiny over its data privacy practices. We're on that story for you coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: After Facebook's data breach and data mining scandal, other big tech companies like Google they are now in the hot seat over their data privacy practices. A new report shows Google is way worse than Facebook at collecting and keeping your personal information. They've been cyberstalking you all over the internet even if you're not on Google's web site for something else.

Let's take a look at how the stock of -- the stock of Google's parent company Alphabet did after their company reporting slide to the downside, and falling to less than 1 percent after hours.

Let's get to the panel on this. I want to bring in Danielle McLaughlin and Kelsey Harkness. First to you, Kelsey, you know what's the creepiest part of the story? It's that this Silicon Valley stalks you all over the internet even though you're not on their web sites. That's the worse part of the story. I don't think people realize that, Kelsey.

KELSEY HARKNESS, SENIOR REPORTER, DAILY SIGNAL: Well, the level of outrage directed at Google and Facebook is certainly understandable, but it's really not surprising because Google and Facebook are billion dollar companies--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Yes, but isn't it creepy that Silicon Valley has all of the information about what we're doing on the internet?

HARKNESS: It's certainly creepy which is why Americans are upset about this, but it's not surprising because they're not providing these services for free. But I think what's important about these stories is that we don't direct our anger towards the government and ask the government to regulate the tech industry because the government, too, is collecting our personal data.

Look at the CFBP, look at OPM, both of them had big, massive breaches. So we need to let the free market solve this, we need to demand that tech companies take it upon themselves to solve this and not get the government involved in an area it really doesn't belong.

MACDONALD: I used to be kind of OK with it, Danielle, and say, OK, you know. But now I'm thinking, wait, this isn't good. To Kelsey's point, the IRS has also had data breaches. The IRS knows a lot about our income. And now Silicon Valley, Danielle knows too much about what we're doing on the internet. I think it's kind of weird.

DANIELLE MCLAUGHLIN, DEMOCRAT STRATEGIST: It is weird, and it is a little bit creepy, to your point. I think we have to make a decision societally about who is going to regulate this. I take Kelsey's point about the notion of the free market solving for this, but the free market hasn't solved for this, and that's why we're in this position in the first place.

I actually do think that more like Europe -- which has very robust privacy laws -- we should ask your government who are elected representative to step in and make sure that these billion, trillion dollar companies in Silicon Valley aren't just data mining.

MACDONALD: Guys, I'm so sorry, we've got to break away because that Senate vote on Mike Pompeo coming in, Rand Paul just now explaining why he changed his vote. Let's listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RAND PAUL, (R) UNITED STATES SENATOR: I decided to go ahead and vote for Director Pompeo because he's assured me that he's learned the lesson. Now, time will tell if those assurances are true or not. And I won't say that -- I can say with absolute certainty I know what his opinions will be and how they will come out over time, but I do take him at his word.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: So they're about to vote, Kelsey, what's your reaction to this 180 out of Senate foreign relations now after that. Now the breaking news it will, that panel will approve Mike Pompeo as secretary of state? What's your reaction to the 180 here?

HARKNESS: I think it's very good news. I think that it maybe appears normal to a lot of Americans to hear that all Democrats are opposing Pompeo's nomination, but this is not normal. Under the Obama administration 94 senators approved both Hillary Clinton and John Kerry for the same position and, clearly, those are very divisive figures.

Mike Pompeo is very qualified to do this job and at a time when we are about to enter into serious negotiations with North Korea, President Trump needs a secretary of state by his side.

MACDONALD: What do you think, Danielle?

MCLAUGHLIN: I do agree that we need a secretary of state at this very crucial time in North Korea relations. What Rand Paul asked of Mike Pompeo was two things, do you agree that war in the Middle East, more war in the Middle East is destabilizing, number one, and number two, do you agree that Iraq was a mistake? He got those reassurances from Mike Pompeo, and that's what changed his vote.

MACDONALD: Interesting. The vote is now underway. We're staying on top of the vote. Final thought, Kelsey.

HARKNESS: I think that this is good news for all Americans.

MACDONALD: OK. Kelsey and Danielle, thank you so much. We're up against a hard break. The president and the president of France about to arrive at Mount Vernon. We're going to stay on that story for you as well. Jam-packed hour, don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Breaking news. The Senate foreign relations committee now voting for Mike Pompeo to be secretary of state. Jeff Flake is yes, so as Rand Paul. It goes to the full chamber for a vote where he is expected to be confirmed as secretary of state.

We're also are waiting for President Trump and the first lady, the French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife. They're headed to Mount Vernon, the home of George Washington to have dinner overlooking the Potomac.

That does it for us. Charles Payne is here now with Making Money.

END

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Being confirmed for you tonight, right now, there are nine people that are dead, 16 that are injured. Toronto police service has mobilized all available resources and I can assure the public all available resources have been brought into address this tragic situation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, HOST, FOX NEWS: Breaking news to the developing situation in Toronto, a driver now in custody after plowing a van into a crowd among Toronto's busiest thoroughfares, nine dead, 16 injured 17 critically.

I am Elizabeth MacDonald. This is Risk & Reward.

The mayor of Toronto authorities just now holding a press conference, the mayor saying it will likely be several days of disruption to the area during the investigation.

Here with more let's get to Kristina Partsinevelos in the newsroom. Kristina?

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: Yes, this event only happened a few hours ago at 1.30 p.m. Eastern Time. A white van from the company Ryder, it's a rental van company plowed on to the sidewalk, what you're seeing right now, started to hit a few pedestrians. According to eye witnesses the pedestrians asked the van to stop, the driver continued going hitting more pedestrians.

And as you mentioned there are nine dead, 16 injured. There's still no word yet about the motivation behind this van attack. You had the mayor just speak very recently, the Mayor of Toronto that's John Tory, and he said we are admired the around the world for being inclusive doesn't want anybody to jump to conclusions just yet as to the motive behind this attack.

Very importantly to note as well, this is the remaining a Toronto investigation not a national investigation with the RCMP, the Royal Canadian Mountain Police, again, this is a Toronto investigation they are not releasing the name of the driver of the van but they were able to bring him into custody.

He seemed uninjured based off of several eye witness videos that I've seen when they caught him, he happened to have something in his hand. There's still no confirmation what he was carrying but he was pointing it at a police officer. There were no shots fired.

Again, this man is in custody. We do not have any details just yet on who he is, what his motivation is, are the Toronto police are being very careful right now with the information, making sure going through to see if he had any cell phones looking through his records to see most importantly if he is somebody that they recognize, that they know and could be affiliated with other people, but right now this is a Toronto investigation.

You have several, 16 people still injured and businesses that have been damaged along the road because this white van went up on to the sidewalk, hit pedestrians, even rammed into a bus station. There was one eye witness that said he saw his family they're looking for their grandfather and they're very worried and I was just listening to this live through Canadian media that they found the grandfather's glasses on the ground and so they're still waiting confirmation.

Several of the patients or victims have been brought to Sunny Brook Hospital in Toronto, again Sunny Brook Hospital, so again we have nine dead, 16 injured in this tragic event that's happening in Toronto as we speak.

MACDONALD: Thank you, Kristina. We'll be staying on top of that story and much more.

Let's get to your money. A widely held stock making lots of 401k plans going up. Google parent company Alphabet reporting solid earnings and revenues better than expected after the bell.

Let's get to Deirdre Bolton on the latest with that. Deirdre?

DEIRDRE BOLTON, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: Hey, Liz. So after-hours, you are going to see this stock kind of see sawing back and forth. So it had a big reaction as you mentioned, Alphabet, Google exceeding both on the top and bottom line and you had a jump of around 4 percent initially, so you can see still higher.

But just coming off those posted session highs, there are still some really big questions out there, Liz, for the long term of this company. You know, Google has between eight to 10 times more data on you and on me than Facebook so a lot of Facebook investors were saying hey, how come Mark Zuckerberg got dragged before Congress?

Google has about eight gigabytes of data per person, that equals about 2,000 hours if we just listen straight through of music. If you want a comparison point Facebook has about 650 megabytes which are smaller than gigabytes and that equals about 160 hours of music. So just an interesting kind of data point and it just shows you where this data power is.

A lot of people are saying Google is one of a kind so if you are an investor you like to hear that. The flip side is, will it make regulators consider one of a kind akin to monopoly which is not too far of a stretch.

We do know that the European regulators are putting in new privacy laws as of May 25th of this year so tech companies, ones that are based here but have customers in Europe, need to be compliant. If these companies are not compliant this is not a small slap on the wrist, Liz, it is between $30 million or 4 percent of annual revenue whichever is higher, so there's a lot of people saying OK, Google has a lot of work ahead. AlphabetGoogle, excuse me. Liz?

MACDONALD: Good to see you, Deirdre. Thank you so much.

We have a jam packed busy hour ahead. We are moments away from President Trump and the first lady welcoming French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife at the White House for the administration's first official state dinner.

Let's get to Blake Burman with the latest. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, CORRESPONDENT, FOX NEWS: At the hour the French president has a busy couple of days here in Washington, Liz. I think you can see behind me that they are expecting Emmanuel Macron here at the White House within the next few minutes or so.

The itinerary is as follows. The Macron family, him and his wife, rather, and the president and first lady will head to dinner tonight to George Washington's home followed by talks tomorrow, a state dinner and then he addresses Congress on Wednesday.

The White House says these two have a great rapport, and part of the reason why he's receiving the first state visit. And I'm hopeful that the new crown prince of Saudi Arabia will be the leader against the radical Islamists in his region so that they are no longer holy warriors and will go to paradise for killing infidels. No, we must destroy that ideology.

MACDONALD: It should be noted too that in Toronto a group of seven security international meeting was occurring just up -- a few blocks away from that terror attack. If we think -- let me back up, we don't know if it's a terror attack, it has the hallmarks of that. Sir, you know, what are the authorities asking this suspect right now?

MCINERNEY: Well, first of all, they want to get his name, and then you want to get where he goes to church, what his basic beliefs are, what is the reason he did this. If one person was killed, fine, that happens. But not nine people. Not nine people.

MACDONALD: General, good to see you, sir. Thank you so much for coming in and handling two stories. I really appreciate it.

MCINERNEY: Thanks, Liz.

MACDONALD: Again, we're going to take you back to the White House. This is -- we're in breaking news mode. The president and first lady welcoming French President Emmanuel Macron and the first lady of France, they're about to leave for Mount Vernon for a dinner overlooking at the Potomac. We will bring it to you live. That is the home of George Washington.

And we're also moments away from that vote out of the Senate panel on the nomination of CIA Director Mike Pompeo as secretary of state. It looks like that panel will vote for Mike Pompeo. Jeff Flake and Rand Paul saying yes to Mike Pompeo as secretary of state.

But first, after Facebook's data breach scandal, other big tech companies like Google could be next to face scrutiny over its data privacy practices. We're on that story for you coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: After Facebook's data breach and data mining scandal, other big tech companies like Google they are now in the hot seat over their data privacy practices. A new report shows Google is way worse than Facebook at collecting and keeping your personal information. They've been cyberstalking you all over the internet even if you're not on Google's web site for something else.

Let's take a look at how the stock of -- the stock of Google's parent company Alphabet did after their company reporting slide to the downside, and falling to less than 1 percent after hours.

Let's get to the panel on this. I want to bring in Danielle McLaughlin and Kelsey Harkness. First to you, Kelsey, you know what's the creepiest part of the story? It's that this Silicon Valley stalks you all over the internet even though you're not on their web sites. That's the worse part of the story. I don't think people realize that, Kelsey.

KELSEY HARKNESS, SENIOR REPORTER, DAILY SIGNAL: Well, the level of outrage directed at Google and Facebook is certainly understandable, but it's really not surprising because Google and Facebook are billion dollar companies--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Yes, but isn't it creepy that Silicon Valley has all of the information about what we're doing on the internet?

HARKNESS: It's certainly creepy which is why Americans are upset about this, but it's not surprising because they're not providing these services for free. But I think what's important about these stories is that we don't direct our anger towards the government and ask the government to regulate the tech industry because the government, too, is collecting our personal data.

Look at the CFBP, look at OPM, both of them had big, massive breaches. So we need to let the free market solve this, we need to demand that tech companies take it upon themselves to solve this and not get the government involved in an area it really doesn't belong.

MACDONALD: I used to be kind of OK with it, Danielle, and say, OK, you know. But now I'm thinking, wait, this isn't good. To Kelsey's point, the IRS has also had data breaches. The IRS knows a lot about our income. And now Silicon Valley, Danielle knows too much about what we're doing on the internet. I think it's kind of weird.

DANIELLE MCLAUGHLIN, DEMOCRAT STRATEGIST: It is weird, and it is a little bit creepy, to your point. I think we have to make a decision societally about who is going to regulate this. I take Kelsey's point about the notion of the free market solving for this, but the free market hasn't solved for this, and that's why we're in this position in the first place.

I actually do think that more like Europe -- which has very robust privacy laws -- we should ask your government who are elected representative to step in and make sure that these billion, trillion dollar companies in Silicon Valley aren't just data mining.

MACDONALD: Guys, I'm so sorry, we've got to break away because that Senate vote on Mike Pompeo coming in, Rand Paul just now explaining why he changed his vote. Let's listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RAND PAUL, (R) UNITED STATES SENATOR: I decided to go ahead and vote for Director Pompeo because he's assured me that he's learned the lesson. Now, time will tell if those assurances are true or not. And I won't say that -- I can say with absolute certainty I know what his opinions will be and how they will come out over time, but I do take him at his word.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: So they're about to vote, Kelsey, what's your reaction to this 180 out of Senate foreign relations now after that. Now the breaking news it will, that panel will approve Mike Pompeo as secretary of state? What's your reaction to the 180 here?

HARKNESS: I think it's very good news. I think that it maybe appears normal to a lot of Americans to hear that all Democrats are opposing Pompeo's nomination, but this is not normal. Under the Obama administration 94 senators approved both Hillary Clinton and John Kerry for the same position and, clearly, those are very divisive figures.

Mike Pompeo is very qualified to do this job and at a time when we are about to enter into serious negotiations with North Korea, President Trump needs a secretary of state by his side.

MACDONALD: What do you think, Danielle?

MCLAUGHLIN: I do agree that we need a secretary of state at this very crucial time in North Korea relations. What Rand Paul asked of Mike Pompeo was two things, do you agree that war in the Middle East, more war in the Middle East is destabilizing, number one, and number two, do you agree that Iraq was a mistake? He got those reassurances from Mike Pompeo, and that's what changed his vote.

MACDONALD: Interesting. The vote is now underway. We're staying on top of the vote. Final thought, Kelsey.

HARKNESS: I think that this is good news for all Americans.

MACDONALD: OK. Kelsey and Danielle, thank you so much. We're up against a hard break. The president and the president of France about to arrive at Mount Vernon. We're going to stay on that story for you as well. Jam-packed hour, don't go away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Breaking news. The Senate foreign relations committee now voting for Mike Pompeo to be secretary of state. Jeff Flake is yes, so as Rand Paul. It goes to the full chamber for a vote where he is expected to be confirmed as secretary of state.

We're also are waiting for President Trump and the first lady, the French President Emmanuel Macron and his wife. They're headed to Mount Vernon, the home of George Washington to have dinner overlooking the Potomac.

That does it for us. Charles Payne is here now with Making Money.

END

value.Title: At Least Nine People Are Dead, 16 Injured And 17 More Are In Critical Condition After A Man Plowed His Van Into Pedestrians In One Of The Busiest Thoroughfares In Toronto, Canada. The Man Is Now In Custody But Toronto Police Has Not Release Yet His Identity; Secretary Of State Nominee Mike Pompeo Is Now Being Voted On The Floor Of The Senate Relations Committee But Democrats Has Oppose His Nomination; Republican Senator Rand Paul First Oppose Pompeo's Nomination But Eventually Said In A Tweet That He Will Support The CIA Director; President Trump With First Lady Melania Welcomes To The White House French President Emmanuel Macron And Wife Brigitte For His First State Visit As President; French President Emmanuel Macron And His Wife Brigitte Gave A Sapling Of Oak Tree As A Gift To President Trump To Plant In The White House. That Sapling Came From Belleau Wood In France Where Over 9,000 American Marines Have Died During World War I; The Voting For CIA Director As Secretary Of State To Replace Rex Tillerson Is Now Underway On The Floor Of The Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
